RUSHING NUMBER OF BLACK
AND BLUE JAY APPEARS
The December Rushing number of the Black and Blue Jay
made its appearance Wednesday.
As may be implied from its
name, the Rushing number dealt
with the new pledgees and the
various sides of fraternity life.
The Black and Blue Jay regrets
to announce the resignation of L.
B. Fenneman as editor-in-chief.
Fenneman has attended the "bird"
since its first peep and has done
much to make it the fat and
healthy publication which now appears. Paul L. Ives was elected
editor-in-chief at a recent meeting held to fill the vacancy.
The Business Staff has announced that a subscription for
the last five issues may be obtained for $1. It has also announced the election of Walsh
and Waldorf, both '26, to the
Business Staff.

ATTENTION, A. A. BOARD
To the Editor-in-Chief of the
Johns Hopkins NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: It recently- occurred
to me that no recognition of any
service performed was given to assistant managers. Although the responsibility falls on the manager,
the assistant managers often bear
a great portion of the work, and I
would suggest to the Athletic
Board that an award in the form
of an FT. A. A. be given to certain
assistant managers in the future.
This award would be some encouragement for juniors and seniors to accept these jobs and would
eliminate the chances of first and
second-year men making these positions when they come out in a halfhearted way to get out of Physical
Training. I do not mean to say
that this was the case in football
this past season, but this thing has
been done before.
I would limit this award merely
to football, except in special cases
in other sports, where the men are
particularly deserving. A. A. Board,
Read! Consider! Act!
Yours in good faith,
HULLABALOO.

some consideration, nothing definite
has been done in any direction.
